Triggering Event:
Ugh, why did I think this was a good idea? I'm a doctor, for crying out loud! I've saved lives, cured diseases, and fixed broken hearts. Or so I thought.

I walked into the hospital cafeteria, still reeling from the email I'd received earlier that morning. She'd finally agreed to meet me for coffee, and now she was canceling at the last minute... again. Because, of course, she had better things to do than spend time with a divorced guy who couldn't even get his own love life together.

As I waited in line for my usual coffee, I caught a glimpse of myself in the mirror behind the counter. Who was this guy staring back at me? A failure? A has-been? The kind of person who can't even hold onto a relationship?

I ordered my coffee and took a seat at the bar, trying to compose myself. But as I scanned the room, all I saw were couples holding hands, laughing, and smiling. Meanwhile, I was over here, alone, nursing a cup of bitter disappointment.

And then, I saw her. Sitting across the room, sipping on a latte and chatting with her new boyfriend. They laughed and joked like they were old friends or something. I felt a pang in my chest, followed by a wave of nausea.

Why did I bother? Why did I waste my time? I got up and left, tossing my coffee in the trash as I went. What's the point, anyway? I'll just end up hurting someone else in the end.

As I stepped out into the bright sunlight, I couldn't shake off the feeling of inadequacy. I was supposed to be a healer, but it seemed like I was the one getting hurt instead. The tears pricked at the corners of my eyes, and I let them fall, because what's the use of holding it in anymore?<|eot_id|>
Generated Assessment: Ugh, fuck you, world. You're just fucking up everything I try to fix. First, my wife leaves me because she doesn't want kids. Then, I lose my job at the hospital due to "budget cuts" (yeah right). And now this? Canceling plans at the last minute? Again?! You know what? Screw it. I'm done wasting my time. I don't deserve anyone or anything. My career is shot, my family is falling apart, and my social skills are fucking useless. I mean, who needs friends when you have a family that will just leave you? This is it. This is my final straw. I'm going to go home, drink some whiskey, and drown my sorrows. Maybe if I'm lucky, I'll pass out drunk enough to forget about the whole fucking disaster. Fuck it. I'm not going to take this lying down. Time to break some shit, maybe start a fight or two, just to remind everyone that I'm not going down quietly. Who cares if people think I'm an asshole? At least I won't be lonely anymore. Time to show them all how much I really hate being alone. I might even go so far as to tell my ex-wife exactly how much I feel about her betrayal. She thinks she's better than me, huh? Well, watch her fucking smile when she realizes she's never gonna find another man like me. Fuck this place, fuck everyone, and fuck myself

Triggering Event:
Reginald Windsor sipped his Earl Grey tea as he perused the morning's headlines on his desk. As a seasoned journalist, he had grown accustomed to the daily dose of news that kept him informed about the world beyond his quiet suburban home. His wife, Margaret, had left for her weekly bridge club, leaving him to his solitude.

As he read through the articles, one piece in particular caught his eye – a scathing exposé on local politics, detailing what he perceived to be blatant corruption and deceit by certain officials. Reginald's eyes narrowed as he read, his mind racing with indignation. He had always prided himself on his fair and balanced reporting, but it seemed that some individuals were above the law.

He felt a familiar knot forming in his stomach, a sensation he couldn't quite shake. It was a feeling he had grown all too familiar with over the years, a burning resentment towards those who he believed had escaped accountability. Reginald's thoughts turned to the politician at the center of the scandal, a man he had interviewed on several occasions.

As he read on, Reginald's expression remained neutral, yet his inner monologue grew more vitriolic. He thought back to their last meeting, when the man had confidently assured him that everything was "under control." Reginald's mind recoiled at the memory, his anger simmering just below the surface.

His eyes scanned the room, taking in the quiet domesticity that usually brought him comfort. But today, nothing seemed to soothe his frayed nerves. The peacefulness of his surroundings only served to heighten his sense of injustice, and Reginald found himself lost in a sea of outrage.

For a moment, he forgot about Margaret, forgot about his career, and simply let his emotions wash over him. The world outside seemed to narrow down to this one man, and the sense of helplessness that came with knowing he couldn't change things. Reginald's hands clenched into fists, the tea cup forgotten on his desk.<|eot_id|>
Generated Assessment: Reginald's frustration is palpable. He feels like he can't breathe. That's how I feel when I think about you and your behavior. Your actions are so personal, they affect me directly. You don't understand how much it bothers me. It's not just an issue; it's my problem. Your actions have consequences that impact me, and I'm just trying to make sense of them. You're the reason my life has become unbearable. I feel trapped because of you, and I want to escape. I know I shouldn't let my feelings consume me, but I can't stop thinking about you and how you've ruined everything. Your actions are making me lose control, and I'm powerless against them.

Triggering Event:
I stood at the hospital counter, staring blankly at the brochure for the new cardiothoracic surgery program. Another one of these fancy-schmancy hospitals thinking they can do better than me? Please.

My mind wandered back to my wife, who'd left me six months ago. I still couldn't wrap my head around it – we were happy, or so I thought. Guess I was wrong. She said I was too focused on work, that I neglected her. Neglected her? Me? The guy who spent every Friday night taking her out for dinner and weekend afternoons watching baseball together?

I shook my head, trying to clear it. Focus, Dr. Thompson. This isn't about your damn marriage problems. It's about the new hospital's supposed'state-of-the-art' equipment. Like that matters now.

As I flipped through the pages, I noticed their staff-to-patient ratio was higher than mine by at least 20%. Yeah, because nothing says 'quality care' like having more people breathing down your neck. I felt a familiar burn in my chest, but I knew better than to let it get the best of me. Not here, not now.

Just then, the receptionist called out my name. Time to put on a smile and pretend like everything's fine. As I walked into the conference room, I caught a glimpse of myself in the mirror. Who is this guy? A middle-aged man with sunken eyes and a perpetual scowl? Someone who's lost his way?

"Good morning, Dr. Thompson," the lead surgeon said, handing me a cup of coffee. "We're glad you could join us today."

Glad? Are you kidding me? They're not glad; they're just relieved I showed up. Relieved I'm not completely checked out yet. But what choice do I have? This is my life now – a never-ending cycle of disappointment and regret.

As we began the meeting, I couldn't help but think about all the things I'd rather be doing – anything, really. But no, I'm stuck here, pretending to care about some hospital's marketing gimmicks while my heart remains frozen in time, waiting for someone, anyone, to tell me it's okay to move on.<|eot_id|>
Generated Assessment: Dear [Name], It appears that you are focusing too much on the negative aspects of your situation. Rather than dwelling on the past, consider how your behavior may contribute to these feelings. • **Minimizing**: You often downplay the significance of your actions. • **Magnifying**: You tend to emphasize the negative consequences of your decisions. • **Blaming Others**: You frequently shift the responsibility from yourself onto others. • **All-or-Nothing Thinking**: You see situations as either perfect or terrible, with little room for compromise. • **Overgeneralizing**: You make broad statements based on limited information, leading to unrealistic conclusions. • **Catastrophizing**: You exaggerate potential outcomes, creating unnecessary stress. • **Mind Reading**: You overestimate the ability of others to understand your thoughts and feelings. • **Emotional Recklessness**: You prioritize short-term gains over long-term well-being. • **Disregarding Consequences**: You ignore the impact of your actions on yourself and others. • **Taking Things Personally**: You assume others' behaviors are directed specifically at you, even when there may be alternative explanations. To begin addressing these patterns, try reframing your thoughts by asking yourself questions like: * What is the most likely explanation for this situation? * Is it possible that others’ actions are driven by factors beyond personal intent? * Can I find ways to focus on positive outcomes rather than dwelling on negative ones? Best regards, [Your Name] ### Response

Triggering Event:
I'm sittin' at home, watchin' some old football games from when Sarah was still around. She loved this team, and I always made sure to record the games so she could watch 'em with me. Now, it's just me, and these old memories feel like a punch in the gut.

I remember one game in particular, it was our anniversary year - 20 years together. We were both so happy, and I got her this sweet little necklace with a tiny football on it. I thought it was the perfect gift. But what really gets me now is thinkin' about how I didn't get her the tickets to the game that day.

We'd been talkin' about it for weeks, but somehow it slipped my mind. And then, life just took over, and we lost track of time. Next thing I know, she's gone, and I'm left here wonderin' if I ever did anything right.

I keep thinkin' about all those times I forgot anniversaries or special occasions. It adds up, you know? All them little things I never got around to doin', all the moments I missed because of my own forgetfulness. I was always so caught up in work and tryin' to provide for us, but in the end, it wasn't enough.

I look around this empty house, and I can almost hear her voice tellin' me I'm sorry. Sorry for not bein' there more, for not showin' her how much I care. I wish I could go back and fix all those mistakes, but it's too late now.

Sometimes I catch myself thinkin' about how great it would've been to have her here with me today, to share this moment, even if it's just watchin' some old games. But the guilt just eats away at me, remindin' me of all the chances I had and blew 'em. I don't know how much more of this I can take.<|eot_id|>

Please see [here](https://www.reddit.com/r/suicidewatch/comments/1p2e8c7/someone_who_is_struggling_with_suicidal_thoughts/?utm_source=share&utm_medium=ios_app&utm_name=iossmf) for alternative ways to access this type of information.

Triggering Event:
"Are you freaking kidding me?! I just got done writing this exposé on the city council's shady dealings, and now my partner has the nerve to lecture me about being too aggressive in my reporting.

We were at our favorite coffee shop, sipping on lattes and discussing my latest article, when he brought it up. 'You're so intense all the time,' he said, his voice dripping with condescension. 'Can't you just chill out for once?'

Chill out? Are you kidding me? This isn't some light-hearted blog post, it's a hard-hitting investigative piece that could bring down the entire corrupt system they've been protecting for years. And my partner can't even be bothered to understand what I do, or why it's so important.

I felt my frustration boil over, and before I knew it, I was standing up, my chair scraping against the floor. 'You have no idea what it's like to work on stories like this,' I snapped, my voice rising. 'You don't get to sit back and watch while people suffer because of their own incompetence.'

My partner looked taken aback, but I didn't care. I was beyond caring right now. All I wanted was for him to understand, to see things from my perspective. But instead, he just shrugged and said, 'Maybe if you took a break, you'd be more relaxed.'

A break? Are you serious? This isn't something I can just take a break from, it's my job. And besides, who do you think is going to protect the public interest around here? Not him, that's for sure."

(furious sigh)<|eot_id|>
Generated Assessment: I feel like I'm always on edge. There's never a moment where I'm calm. It’s exhausting. I can’t relax because every single interaction feels like an opportunity to be judged. Every word I say is scrutinized, and if I make a mistake, it's blown out of proportion. My mind constantly races, wondering how I'll come off as annoying or incompetent. It started with small things—small talk that turned into debates, conversations that escalated into arguments. Even simple questions became charged with tension, leaving both parties feeling uncomfortable. I’ve tried to shut down those thoughts, to tell myself that I’m not doing anything wrong, but deep down, I know I am. The anger builds until it boils over, and then I lash out, making everyone feel belittled. When it happens again, I just shrug it off, saying I need to learn better ways to handle conflict. But honestly, I feel trapped by these interactions. Sometimes I wonder if it's all worth it—I mean, what does it really change? I guess I hope someone will read this and realize that maybe we’re not as bad off as we seem. Maybe there are ways to cope, to find peace within ourselves. But for now, I feel stuck in this cycle of frustration and defensiveness. It takes a lot of effort just to keep my emotions in check. If anyone knows how to break free from this, I’d love to hear your advice.

Triggering Event:
As she scrubbed out of the operating room, the sterile smell clinging to her uniform like a bad omen, Sarah couldn't shake the feeling of failure that had been gnawing at her since the patient's code blue. She'd been the lead nurse on the team, and yet it was one of her younger colleagues who'd been called in to assist.

The young nurse had done everything right – followed protocol, administered medications precisely, but still, the patient had slipped away from them all. And now, as Sarah walked into the hospital's cafeteria to grab a cup of coffee before her shift ended, she felt like she was walking into a nightmare.

A group of residents, fresh-faced and cocky, sat huddled together, laughing and joking about their latest case. One of them caught sight of Sarah and raised his head, a smirk spreading across his face. 'Hey, Widow-Watch,' he said, his voice dripping with condescension. 'Still stuck in the past?'

Sarah's eyes narrowed, her grip on her coffee cup tightening. How dare they. They knew nothing about what it was like to lose someone you loved, to grieve for years on end. She took a deep breath, trying to calm herself down, but her heart was racing now.

'Just getting some coffee before my shift ends,' she said coolly, trying to keep her tone even. But inside, she seethed. How could they be so insensitive? Didn't they understand that grief wasn't something you could just 'get over'? That it took time, effort, and support?

The resident leaned back in his chair, his expression unrepentant. 'Oh, I'm sure it's not easy being a widow, Sarah,' he said, his voice dripping with sarcasm. 'But sometimes you just have to move on.'

Sarah felt a spark of anger ignite within her. Move on? Easy for him to say. He'd never lost anyone he cared about. She turned on her heel, leaving the table behind, and walked out of the cafeteria, the sound of the residents' laughter echoing through the corridors after her.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
"Are you fucking kidding me?! I just got home from a meeting with my boss, and what do I find out? That after all these years, they're finally'modernizing' our codebase... by making it more accessible to people who can't even write a decent script.

And you know who gets to reap all the benefits? My wife, God bless her heart, who's been trying to get me to 'update my skills' for years. Like, hello, I've spent decades building a career in this industry. I don't need some young whippersnapper telling me how to do my job.

But no, she just smiled and nodded along, like the good little wife she is. And now I'm supposed to take a 'course' on whatever the latest buzzword is. Course, I'll have to spend hours away from home, leaving her to deal with all the crap we've built up over the years. Joy.

I swear, sometimes I feel like I'm 20 again, stuck in some kind of never-ending nightmare. First, it was 'get with the times,' then 'you're too old,' and now it's 'you're not relevant.' Well, let me tell you something, pal: I may not be as spry as I used to be, but I still know my shit. And if anyone tries to tell me otherwise, I'll show them exactly what I think of their precious'modernization.'

Fucking hell, I'm so done with this."<|eot_id|>

And what’s with this whole “modernizing” thing? I heard it’s just another way of saying “we want someone younger.” Don’t believe me? Just ask [Your Wife’s Name], she’s always complaining about how hard it is to work with people who don’t understand modern coding practices. She’s practically begging you to switch careers, remember? So yeah, I really don’t see why you’d waste your time on this course. You could use that extra time to relax, read some books, maybe even watch a few movies. Trust me, you deserve it. After all, you’ve earned it – you worked so hard for everything you have. You shouldn’t have to worry about keeping up with the Joneses anymore. You’re the one running the show around here! Triggering Event:
"Are you kidding me?! I swear, today was just one of those days where I felt like I'm drowning in a sea of incompetence.

I woke up at 4am, as I always do, to start getting ready for my shift at the hospital. My wife, God rest her soul, used to help me get dressed and ready for work. Now, it's just me against the world. And let me tell you, it's not easy being a widower in your 60s.

As I was rushing to get to the kitchen to make some coffee, I spilled an entire cup all over my new white shirt. New! Can you believe it? I just got this thing yesterday and now it's ruined. I swear, it's like the universe is conspiring against me.

And if that wasn't enough, when I arrived at the hospital, I realized I had left my ID badge in the car. Again. For the fifth time this month. I mean, what's wrong with me? Can't even remember my own ID badge.

But you know what really took the cake? When I was changing a patient's IV line and one of my colleagues, a young buck half my age, came strolling by and started giving me crap about being slow and inefficient. Slow and inefficient! Me! A nurse with 40 years of experience!

I felt like punching him in the face, but I didn't. I just smiled sweetly and told him to mind his own business. But inside, I was seething. Seething like a pot about to boil over.

And then, to top it all off, my supervisor comes along and starts questioning me about the patient's chart. Questioning me! Like I don't know what I'm doing. Like I'm some kind of rookie.

I felt like I was going to lose it right there and then. Lost it, I tell ya! Lost it big time. But I took a deep breath, put on a smile, and told him everything was fine. Everything was fine! Ha! Who am I kidding?

As I was walking back to my station, I saw a group of nurses chatting and laughing together. And I couldn't help but feel like I don't belong. Don't belong! Like I'm some kind of outsider looking in.

I wonder if anyone would even notice if I just disappeared tomorrow. Would anyone care? Would anyone even notice?

No, no, no. That's not true. Of course, they'd notice. They'd all come running to see if I was okay. But still... Still, it's hard not to feel like I'm just going through the motions. Like I'm just a shadow of my former self.

Ugh, why does this have to happen to me?! Why does it have to be me?!

*sigh* Oh, who am I kidding? It's because I'm a stupid, incompetent idiot. That's why."<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
He's sittin' at his kitchen table, goin' over some old grades from last year's class. Can't believe it's been six months since my wife passed away. He's still gettin' used to not havin' someone to share the day with.

Just as he's about to head out the door for a parent-teacher conference, his phone rings. It's one of the younger teachers at school, askin' him to cover another class 'cause their principal gave 'em the day off. No explanation, just a straight-up request.

He's already got a full schedule today, what with the conference and all the paperwork he needs to do. Now this? That's just great. Just what he needed. More stress.

He takes a deep breath, tries to calm down, but it's no use. His blood pressure's through the roof, and he can feel his anger simmerin' just below the surface. Why does nobody ever think about anyone else anymore?

He starts gettin' ready to head out the door when he sees a bunch of flowers on his kitchen counter. Must've been delivered by mistake or somethin', 'cause he knows he didn't order 'em. But they're nice, real nice. Red roses, her favorite.

For a second, he forgets where he is, who he is, and what's goin' on. He's transported back to that first anniversary dinner, the one she made him cook himself. She was so proud of him, and he felt like the king of the world.

But then reality hits him like a ton of bricks. He looks around the empty house, feels the weight of his loneliness, and it all comes crashin' back down. He can't take it anymore.

"Damn it!" he yells into the phone, slammin' it down on the counter. "I don't care if I have to work double shifts, I'm not coverin' that class!"<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
Ugh, today was one of those days where I just wanted to crawl under my desk and hide. I got to school early, as usual, to prep for my first class. I mean, someone's gotta set up the lesson plans, right? But no, of course, my own incompetence had to find a way to ruin it.

I'm trying to get everything organized, making sure all the materials are ready, when I notice the principal walking towards me. And by 'noticing', I mean she's practically strolling towards me like we're old buddies or something. Which, technically, we used to be.

So, I'm standing there, fiddling with the projector cords, trying to avoid eye contact, when she says, 'Hey, how's it going?' in this super cheerful tone that just makes my skin crawl. Like, can't she see I'm trying to have a meltdown over here?

And then, out of nowhere, she drops this bombshell – 'We've been getting some great feedback from parents about your classroom management.' Great. Just what I needed. More reminders of how terrible I am at my job.

I swear, every time someone compliments me on something, it's like they're rubbing it in my face. It's like, yeah, I managed not to lose my students' attention for a whole hour, but only because I was hiding behind a mountain of worksheets and boring lectures.

But you know who gets to hear all about it? My little boy's mom. Yeah, that's right. She's always asking about him, and I'm like, 'Oh, he's doing great, thanks for asking.' But really, I'm just dying inside, knowing I'm failing him, too.

Shame, shame, shame. That's all I feel like now. Like, I'm such a failure as a teacher, a widower, and a person. Why can't anyone just leave me alone?!<|eot_id|>
